head.title: Expect Gas Prices To Keep Going Up

hedline.hl1: Expect Gas Prices To Keep Going Up

block.p: As evidenced by recent Business Day articles (April 11 and 17), consumers are facing steadily increasing gasoline prices as a result of rapidly increasing demand. This textbook supply-and-demand relationship is being worsened by omissions and commissions perpetrated in Washington that are letting energy demand soar and pushing prices up.

As evidenced by recent Business Day articles (April 11 and 17), consumers are facing steadily increasing gasoline prices as a result of rapidly increasing demand. This textbook supply-and-demand relationship is being worsened by omissions and commissions perpetrated in Washington that are letting energy demand soar and pushing prices up.

For example, we expect legislation that was enacted last year to increase the national speed limit to result in heightened demand of seven million gallons a day, costing more than $3 billion annually and increasing oil imports by 10 percent.

A new proposal to vitiate the executive branch's ability to raise Federal fuel-economy standards will, in our view, cut down the nation's most successful oil-demand reduction effort. These standards have already saved the typical buyer of a new car an average of $3,300 at the gas pump over the life of the car and lessened the country's oil demand by three million barrels a day.

Congress has refused full financing of a research effort between the Federal Government and automakers that is intended to triple fuel efficiency performance. Meantime, the Federal budget for operating assistance for mass transit was hit: the President proposed a 37 percent cut and Congress approved a 50 percent cut.

In the past year, Congress has cut the Administration's request for energy efficiency and alternative energy sources by one-third, leading to delays in bringing about new technologies and applications that will help lessen demand for gasoline, heating oil and other fossil fuels.
As long as demand for gasoline and other finite energy sources keeps going up faster than supplies, price increases for drivers will stay in the fast lane.
